awd_titl_txt: RUI: The role of mitotic trafficking in cell fate specification
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Paragraph:

In developing embryos, the type of tissue that a cell becomes is primarily determined by signals each cell receives from its neighbors.  These same signals also regulate the behavior of fully functional cells in adult tissues.  Defects in cell signaling are the cause of many birth defects and can also cause cancer cells to form.  Although great strides have been made in understanding the molecular basis of cell signaling, most of this work has been conducted in cells that are not dividing.  The effect of cell division on cell response to signals remains poorly understood.  This project will help fill this crucial gap by examining the interplay between cell division and signaling.  The proposed experiments will examine how proteins that receive signals from neighboring cells are moved around inside dividing cells.  Because both cancer cells and embryonic cells frequently divide, the distribution of these signal-receiver proteins during cell division is likely to play a crucial role in creating embryonic cell identity and in promoting cancerous cell behaviors. This proposal will also promote intensive training of diverse undergraduate researchers in designing and carrying out independent research projects.  The project will also promote public education through interactions with many well-established outreach programs in the Philadelphia area.

Technical Paragraph:

Cell fate induction is affected by trafficking of signal components.  Recent studies have overturned the long-held assumption that membrane trafficking is shut down during mitosis.  Thus, mitotic trafficking of signaling components may play a profound, largely unrecognized role in cell fate specification.  The long-term goal of the PI is to understand how cell division affects inductive signal processing.  This question is addressed by examining heart progenitor induction in the basal chordate, Ciona intestinalis.  The PI has exploited the extreme cellular simplicity of Ciona embryos to perform high-resolution, in vivo analysis of inductive signaling mechanisms, and focuses on Fibroblast Growth Factor (FGF)-dependent induction of the heart progenitor lineage.  Mitotic redistribution of FGF receptors (FGFRs) was found to promote differential heart progenitor induction.  The PI hypothesizes that mitotic kinases regulate trafficking of FGFR-enriched adherent domains, and will test this hypothesis through the following specific aims: 1) Characterization of mitotic trafficking of FGFR-enriched signaling domains through image analysis of tagged proteins in live, intact embryos; 2) Delineation of the role of specific endocytic pathways in signaling domain redistribution through co-localization analysis using pathway-specific markers and targeted disruption of pathway-specific components;  3) Determination of how mitotic kinases affect endocytic trafficking of FGFR-enriched domains through targeted disruption of kinase activity.  Completion of the proposed studies will provide fundamental insights regarding the interplay between division and signaling in both embryonic and stem cells.

por.por_cntn:
Funding provided by this NSF grant has led to fundamental insights regarding the interplay between cell division and signaling, provided invaluable training opportunities for both students and post-doctoral fellows while also supporting two substantive outreach initiatives.

 

The primary focus of funded research was to investigate the way that cell division impacts how cells respond to signals. In particular, we focused on the trafficking of signal receptors during division. Receptors serve as cellular antennae, allowing cells to sense cues present in their environment and respond appropriately. Cells often internalize these receptors, blocking their response to some signals, and then either degrade or recycle them back to the surface. This process of receptor trafficking is well studied in non-dividing cells and errors in receptor trafficking are thought to have important roles in human disease. Surprisingly, almost nothing was known about how cells traffic their receptors as they divide and how changes in receptor trafficking may alter the ability of dividing cells to respond to their environment. We studied this question in the embryos of a marine organism called a sea squirt or tunicate. Sea squirts are powerful models for this kind of research because they are chordates, a related group of animals that includes humans and other vertebrates. Despite this close relationship sea squirt embryos are constructed from very low numbers of cells and have simple genomes with less copies of key signaling genes, making it easier to decipher fundamental questions about division and signaling. We looked at receptor trafficking in embryonic cells that form the heart. We were able to track the movement of receptors in these cells in intact embryos and then manipulate key molecular switches that control cell division to see how receptor trafficking was impacted.  Our results support a model in which two of these key switches cooperatively promote receptor internalization during entry into division by suppressing degradation and inhibiting recycling. Internalization of receptors may help ensure that dividing cells do not respond to external cues. As cells exit division, internalized receptors are re-distributed and cells can control this process to change the response of one or both of their daughter cells. In the embryonic heart cells that we study, unequal redistribution of these receptors ensures that only one daughter cell continues to form the heart while the other become a tail muscle cell.  Thus, these insights can help us better understand how signals control the identity of embryonic cells, helping to ensure organs such as the heart are properly constructed. These insights also have important implications for cancer biology as cancer is driven by disruptions in cell signaling leading to rapid, uncontrolled division. Mutations in genes that regulate signaling during division may thus be hotspots for cancer and other human diseases. More broadly, this research highlights the importance of using a wide range of model organisms to study fundamental biological questions that can have important implications for human health.

 

This grant has helped to support 16 undergraduate research fellows, including 10 women and 5 underrepresented minorities providing them opportunities for substantive, independent engagement in scientific research. Five of these students were co-authors on resulting manuscripts, including two first authorships and we are currently drafting a manuscript that will include authorship of 5 additional students. This grant has also provided substantive training opportunities for three post-docs, one of whom was first author on a high impact manuscript detailing the major findings resulting from this research. She was able to leverage her training and accomplishments to obtain a tenure track position. The other two post-docs are continuing to conduct funded research projects. Additionally, this support allowed the recruitment of local high school teachers from an underserved school to develop and teach an engaging, interactive course focused on the central role of cell communication in developing embryos and cancer in the science for kids summer outreach program. In this program students from nearby underserved school districts in Chester come to Swarthmore to learn about science while engaging with Swarthmore faculty and undergraduates. Additionally, this funding supported a separate outreach program in which the primary investigator worked with a group of high school students from underserved schools through an established program at the Mutter Museum to help these students understand the links between cell signaling and cancer. The students then created and displayed a museum exhibit relaying these concepts to the public.
